questions.text:
A child presents with acute exacerbation of asthma. Which of the following would you do?


	Chest X-ray
	Oxygen administration
	Salbutamol nebulization three times in 60 minutes
	Administration of oral corticosteroids
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 2, 3, 4

 

Explanation: In acute asthma exacerbation, oxygen administration, salbutamol nebulization, and oral corticosteroids are essential to stabilize the patient, while a chest X-ray is not routinely needed unless alternative diagnoses or complications are suspected.

 

Management of Acute Asthma attacks

Immediate Treatment
  • Oxygen Therapy (2): Administer via mask or nasal cannula to maintain SpO2 > 92%.
  • Inhaled SABAs (3):
    • Albuterol: 2.5 mg/3 mL nebulized every 20 mins for 3 doses;
    • Levalbuterol: 1.25 mg/0.5 mL up to 3 doses every 20 mins.
  • Systemic Corticosteroids (4):
    • Prednisone: 1-2 mg/kg/day orally (max 60 mg/day);
    • Methylprednisolone: 1-2 mg/kg IV, then oral dosing.

Adjunctive Treatments
  • Inhaled Anticholinergics, Ipratropium Bromide: 0.5 mg nebulized every 6-8 hours as needed.
  • Intravenous Magnesium Sulfate: 25-75 mg/kg IV over 20 minutes (max 2 grams).

Escalation of Care
  • Continuous Nebulization:
    • Albuterol: 10-15 mg/hour via nebulizer.
  • Parenteral β-Agonists:
    • Terbutaline: 2-10 µg/kg IV loading dose followed by 0.1-0.4 microgram/kg/min titrate in 0.1-0.2 µg/kg/min increments every 30 min
    • Epinephrine: 0.01 mg/kg SC or IM, repeat every 15-30 min if needed.

Monitoring & Management
  • Close Monitoring:
    • Continuous monitoring of vital signs, oxygen saturation, and clinical response. Assess improvement in symptoms, PEF, and lung function.
  • Risk Assessment for Discharge:
    • Criteria: Sustained improvement, PEF > 70% predicted, oxygen saturation > 92% on room air. Ensure home capability for medication administration.

questions.text: A child presents with recurrent sinusitis and repeated lung infections. Genetic testing shows a mutation in the CFTR gene. Which test is considered the gold standard to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Sweat chloride test:

Explanation: The child’s recurrent sinusitis, repeated lung infections, and confirmed CFTR gene mutation are suggestive of cystic fibrosis (CF).

  • The gold standard diagnostic test for CF is the quantitative pilocarpine iontophoresis sweat chloride test.

Cystic Fibrosis is an autosomal recessive disease that can be detected via sweat chloride test in newborns.

  • Pancreatic insufficiency is seen in more than 85% of children with CF and leads to malabsorption, resulting in symptoms like failure to thrive, frequent greasy stools, and weight gain difficulties.

Clinical Features of Cystic Fibrosis by Age Group

Age Group

Sinopulmonary

Gastrointestinal

Renal, Endocrine, Other

Infancy
  • Infection
  • Fetal echogenic bowel
  • Meconium ileus
  • Pancreatic insufficiency
  • Rectal prolapse
  • Dehydration
  • Hyponatremic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis

Childhood
  • Infection
  • ABPA
  • Polyposis
  • Sinusitis
  • DIOS (Distal Intestinal Obstruction Syndrome)
  • Intussusception
  • Hepatic steatosis, biliary fibrosis
  • Rectal prolapse
  • Renal calculi
  • Hyponatremic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis

Adolescence/Adulthood
  • Infection
  • ABPA
  • Haemoptysis
  • Pneumothorax
  • Respiratory failure
  • Sinusitis, Polyposis, Anosmia
  • DIOS
  • Intussusception
  • Biliary fibrosis, cirrhosis
  • Digestive tract cancer (adenocarcinoma)
  • Delayed puberty, osteoporosis, CFRD (Cystic Fibrosis-Related Diabetes)
  • Renal calculi, renal failure
  • CBAVD (Congenital Bilateral Absence of the Vas Deferens), HPOA (Hypertrophic Pulmonary Osteoarthropathy)
  • Arthritis, vasculitis
  • Hyponatremic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis

Diagnostic Criteria for Cystic Fibrosis

Diagnostic Criteria

Requirement

Any ONE of the following:

Clinical Features

Presence of typical features (respiratory, gastrointestinal, or genitourinary)

Family History

A sibling with diagnosed cystic fibrosis

Newborn Screening Test
  • Positive result indicating risk for cystic fibrosis
  • Immunoreactive trypsinogen (IRT) is the first-line screen, which identifies babies with pancreatic insufficiency, one of the hallmarks of CF.

PLUS at least ONE:

Laboratory Evidence of CFTR Dysfunction
  • Two elevated sweat chloride concentrations on separate days
  • Pilocarpine iontophoresis: Used to diagnose cystic fibrosis in infants by estimating sweat chloride ion levels; elevated chloride levels (≥60 mMol/L) in sweat are indicative of the condition.
  • Identification of two CFTR mutations
  • An abnormal nasal potential difference measurement

Incorrect Options:

Lung biopsy (Option B): Rarely indicated; not used for diagnosis of CF.

Chest X-ray (Option C): May show bronchiectasis or hyperinflation but is nonspecific.

Nasal swab culture (Option D): May detect organisms like Pseudomonas aeruginosa, but does not confirm CF.

questions.text: A 4-month-old infant is brought to the emergency department with a respiratory rate of 66 breaths per minute, along with chest indrawing and nasal flaring. There are no other significant findings. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Pneumonia

Explanation: In infants aged 2–12 months, WHO IMNCI (Integrated Management of Neonatal and Childhood Illness) classifies:

  • Pneumonia: Cough or difficulty breathing with fast breathing (≥50 breaths/min in 2–12 months) without danger signs.
  • Severe pneumonia: Cough or difficulty breathing plus any danger sign (e.g., chest indrawing with general danger signs such as inability to feed, lethargy, convulsions, hypoxia).

Classification

Signs

Treatment

Severe Pneumonia or Very Severe Disease

Any general danger sign

OR

  • Oxygen saturation <90%
  • Stridor in calm child
  • Central cyanosis
  • Convulsions
  • AVPU = V, P, or U
  • Start oxygen therapy if saturation < 90%.
  • Administer Benzyl Penicillin & Gentamicin.
  • Give diazepam if convulsing.
  • Prevent low blood sugar.
  • Treat wheeze if present.
  • Urgent referral or admission.

Pneumonia

Chest indrawing in calm child

OR

Fast breathing

AND

No signs of severe pneumonia
  • Administer Amoxicillin Dispersible Tablet.
  • Give Vitamin A.
  • Treat wheeze if present.
  • Follow up in 5 days
  • Advise on immediate return signs.

No Pneumonia: Cough or Cold

No signs of pneumonia or very severe disease
  • Treat wheeze if present - salbutamol for 5 days
  • Advise on immediate return signs.

In this case:

  • Age = 4 months (threshold for tachypnea ≥50/min; child has 66/min).
  • Signs = Chest indrawing, nasal flaring, but no danger signs like inability to feed, cyanosis, altered consciousness.
    • Fits pneumonia classification, not severe pneumonia.

Incorrect Options:

Severe pneumonia (Option B): Requires danger signs or hypoxia; not present here.

Severe asthma (Option C): Rare in infants; asthma usually diagnosed in older children with recurrent wheezing.

Common cold (Option D): No tachypnea or significant respiratory distress.

questions.text: During infancy, what is the most prevalent causative agent of acute bronchiolitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D- Respiratory syncytial virus

Explanation:

  • The most common etiological agent responsible for acute bronchiolitis in infants is Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV).

Bronchiolitis

Age Group

Infants between 1 and 6 months, but can affect children up to 2 years old.

Seasonality

Occurs primarily in winter and spring.

Causative Agent
  • Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) (Most common)
  • Others include:
    • Parainfluenza virus (Option B)
    • Adenovirus
    • Influenza virus (Option A)
    • Rarely Mycoplasma pneumoniae.

Risk factors
  • M/c in male infants.
  • Infants exposed to tobacco smoke, not breastfed, or living in crowded conditions.
  • Maternal smoking
  • Older family members/siblings (common source of infection)

Protection
  • IgG3 antibodies (short half-life, limited placental transfer)
  • Breastfeeding provides IgA antibodies.

Pathophysiology
  • Bronchiolar obstruction with edema, mucus and cellular debris.
  • Increased airway resistance during both inspiration and exhalation.
  • Leads to expiratory wheezing, air trapping, lung hyperinflation and possible atelectasis.
  • Hypoxemia due to ventilation-perfusion mismatch.
  • With severe obstructive disease hypercapnia develops.

Clinical Manifestations
  • First develop upper respiratory symptoms: Sneezing and clear rhinorrhea.
  • Fever (±)
  • Diminished appetite
  • Persistent Cough
  • Dyspnea
  • Irritability
  • Respiratory distress
  • Cyanosis.

Physical Examination
  • Prolonged expiratory time
  • Wheezing
  • Increased work of breathing with nasal flaring and retractions
  • Accessory muscles of respiration are working
  • Auscultation: Fine crepitations and rhonchi
  • Faint or inaudible breath sounds in severe disease

questions.text: What is the most suitable course of action for managing a one and a half year old child who was brought to the hospital presenting symptoms of breathlessness, fever, cough, and cold, and upon examination has a respiratory rate of 46 breaths per minute, chest retractions, but no danger signs were present?

choices.text: Give IV antibiotics and refer to higher centre
Oral antibiotics, warn of danger signs, and send home
No need of treatment only home remedies

questions.solution:
Correct Answer C- Oral antibiotics, warn of danger signs, and send home

Explanation:

  • The clinical manifestations indicate pneumonia based on WHO IMCI guidelines. The child presents with fast breathing (>40/min for ages 1-5 years) and chest retractions without any general danger signs.
  • According to standard guidelines, this classification of pneumonia requires oral antibiotic therapy (5-day course of oral amoxicillin) with careful monitoring at home, rather than hospitalization or intravenous antibiotics.

Pneumonia Classification: WHO IMNCI Guidelines

Signs

Classify as

Treatment

Presence of any general danger sign

Severe pneumonia or very severe disease

Give 1 dose of inj ampicillin & gentamycin & refer urgently to hospital

Presence of either chest indrawing &/or fast breathing but no general danger sign

Pneumonia
  • Start oral Amoxicillin x 5 days.
  • The child is sent home and assessed after 48 hours.
  • If the child has improved, continue the same treatment.
  • If the child has worsened, refer to a higher center.

No fast breathing, no chest indrawing, no general danger signs

No pneumonia: cough or cold only

Home-based supportive care

Fast Breathing Criteria:

  • < 2 months: > 60/min
  • 2-12 months: > 50/min
  • 1-5 years: > 40/min

General Danger signs:

  1. Convulsions
  2. Lethargy
  3. Inability to drink or breastfeed
  4. Persistent vomiting
  5. Unconsciousness
  6. Stridor in a calm child

Incorrect Options:

Give IV antibiotics and observe (Option A): IV antibiotics are reserved for severe pneumonia or cases with danger signs. This level of intervention is not warranted for a case without danger signs and represents overtreatment.

Give IV antibiotics and refer to higher centre (Option B): Referral to a higher center is indicated only for severe cases with danger signs such as lethargy, inability to drink, or persistent vomiting. The child's current presentation does not warrant this level of care.

No need of treatment only home remedies (Option D): This approach would be appropriate for cases with no fast breathing and no chest retractions. Given the presence of tachypnea and retractions, antibiotics are necessary, making home remedies alone insufficient.

questions.text: Which of the following should be administered in addition to airway management for a 3-year-old child experiencing symptoms such as rapid breathing, high fever, noisy breathing during inhalation, and difficulty swallowing with excessive saliva production within 4-6 hours of the onset of fever?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) IV ceftriaxone

Explanation:

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute epiglottitis. The primary treatment for acute epiglottitis is the prompt administration of intravenous antibiotics, such as ceftriaxone or cefotaxime.

Acute Epiglottitis

Life-threatening infection that causes profound swelling of the upper airways, which can lead to asphyxia and respiratory arrest.

 

Causative Agent

  • Past Era (Pre-vaccine): Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib)

  • Post-vaccine Era:

    • Streptococcus pneumoniae (M/c), Streptococcus pyogenes, non-typeable H. influenzae, and Staphylococcus aureus

    • Hib cases have decreased by 99% due to widespread vaccination.

Clinical Features

  • Child appears toxic with high fever, rapid breathing.

  • Difficulty swallowing with excessive saliva production (drooling).

  • Neck hyperextension to maintain airway, Tripod position (sitting upright, leaning forward)

  • Stridor (noisy breathing during inhalation) is a late sign indicating near-complete airway obstruction.

  • Cyanosis, Coma.

Diagnosis

  • Laryngoscopy: Large, cherry-red, swollen epiglottis

 

  • Lateral neck X-ray: Thumb sign

Treatment

  • Immediate Treatment:

    • Secure airway.

    • Intubation decreases mortality from 6% to <1% in epiglottitis cases.

    • Culture Collection: Blood, epiglottic surface and CSF in certain cases after the airway is stabilized.

  • Antibiotics: Ceftriaxone, cefepime or meropenem given parenterally for 10 days.

Recovery

Symptoms improve with a few days of antibiotics, and the patient may be extubated.

questions.text: A baby assessed 5 minutes after birth is found to be pink, with blue extremities and irregular respiration. The heart rate is 80 beats per minute. There is a grimace and some flexion. What is the APGAR score for this baby?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 5

Explanation:

In the given case:

  • Appearance: Pink body with blue extremities (score = 1)
  • Pulse rate: 80 beats/min (score = 1)
  • Grimace: Shows grimace (score = 1)
  • Activity: Some flexion (score = 1)
  • Respiratory effort: Irregular breathing (score = 1)

Therefore, the total score is 5.

 

APGAR score:

  • The APGAR score is an objective method of evaluating the newborn’s condition.
  • It is performed at 1 minute and again at 5 minutes after birth.
  • Resuscitation must be initiated before the 1 minute score is assigned. Therefore, it is not used to guide the resuscitation.

2

Appearance

Completely blue or pale

The body is pink, and the extremities are blue

Completely pink

Interpretation:

  • Normal APGAR score is ≥7
  • Maximum score = 10; Minimum score = 0
  • Score for severe birth asphyxia = 0 - 3

questions.text: Which of the following PFT findings in a child do not suggest asthma?

choices.text: Increase in FEV1 > 12% after salbutamol inhalation

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Day-night variation of FEV1 >15%

Explanation:

  • In asthma, lung function typically shows significant variability during the day, but the day-night variation of FEV1 is usually <15%. A variation >15% may indicate other conditions such as sleep apnea, or vocal cord dysfunction.

 

Investigations of Asthma:

  • Spirometry: Airflow limitation:
    • Low FEV1 (relative to the percentage of predicted norms)
    • FEV1/FVC ratio <0.80 (Option B)
  • Bronchodilator response (to inhaled ß-agonist) assesses reversibility
    • Reversibility is determined by an increase in either FEV1 >12% or
    • Predicted FEV1 >12% after inhalation of a short-acting ß-agonist (SABA) (Option A)
  • Exercise challenge: Worsening in FEV1 ≥15% (Option D)
  • Daily peak expiratory flow (PEF) or FEV1 monitoring: Day-to-day and/or AM-to-PM variation ≥ 20%
  • Exhaled nitric oxide (FeNO):
    • A value of >20 ppb supports the clinical diagnosis of asthma in children
    • FeNO can be used to predict response to ICS therapy
  • Chest Radiographs:
    • Chest radiographs often appear normal. May show subtle signs such as hyperinflation (flattening of the diaphragms) and peribronchial thickening
  • Allergy Testing: Assesses sensitization to inhalant allergens.

questions.text: A 5-year-old male with a known history of asthma developed sudden onset breathlessness and wheezing. He was rushed to the emergency, where the preliminary assessment was done. The pulse is 140/min, respiratory rate 28/min, and the FEV1 is 40% of the predicted value. Which of the following is the best next step in treatment in this case?

choices.text: A high concentration of oxygen should be given by a face mask + Salbutamol nebulization
High doses of SABA to be given by a nebulizer only
Sedatives should be added to alleviate anxiety
Nebulized anticholinergics to be added immediately as the mainstay of treatment

questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - A high concentration of oxygen should be given by a face mask + Salbutamol nebulization

  • The FEV1 of 40%, tachypnea and tachycardia suggest that the acute exacerbation of asthma here is of the severe type that should be managed by providing oxygen therapy and salbutamol nebulization.

Life-Threatening Asthma Management

Overview
  • Most severe asthma exacerbations require immediate attention.
  • Indicators: Cyanosis, silent chest, poor respiratory effort, exhaustion, altered mental state, PEF <30%, oxygen saturation <90%.

Immediate Management
  • Oxygen Therapy: Administer for hypoxemia.
  • Systemic Bronchodilators: Terbutaline or adrenaline subcutaneously; inhaled bronchodilators (salbutamol, ipratropium).
  • Systemic Corticosteroids: IV hydrocortisone (5 mg/kg).
  • ICU Transfer: For monitoring and advanced care.

ICU Management
  • Continuous Monitoring: Vital signs, oxygen saturation, PEF.
  • If Improvement Noted:
    • Continue inhaled bronchodilators (salbutamol/terbutaline) every 20-30 minutes.
    • Maintain hydrocortisone at 2-3 mg/kg every 6-8 hours until the patient can take oral medication.
  • If No Improvement or Deterioration:
    • Consider slow intravenous infusion of magnesium sulfate (50 mg/kg).
    • Alternatively, administer a loading dose of theophylline.
  • If these measures fail, prepare for mechanical ventilation.
  • Address Underlying Causes: Check for acidosis, pneumothorax, electrolyte imbalance, and infection.

Options B, C, and D are insufficient methods for the treatment of severe acute exacerbation of asthma and are hence incorrect.

questions.text: The following image is of the most common cause of stridor in children. Identify it.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Laryngomalacia

  • The given image is a laryngoscopic view showing floppy tissues above the vocal cords and the inward curving of the epiglottis (omega sign) which points to the most common cause of stridor in children, laryngomalacia.

Laryngomalacia

Definition
  • M/c congenital laryngeal anomaly in children; characterized by floppy tissues above the vocal cords that collapse during inspiration, causing stridor.
  • Accounts for 45% to 75% of stridor cases in infants.

Onset

Appear within the first 2 weeks of life and can worsen for up to six months, with gradual improvement often occurring thereafter.

Factors deciding severity and clinical course
  • Gastroesophageal reflux disease
  • Laryngopharyngeal reflux disease
  • Neurological conditions

Investigations
  • Diagnosis is made mainly by clinical symptoms.
  • Outpatient flexible laryngoscopy is done to confirm the diagnosis but is not suitable for a baby as well as when dysphagia is suspected.
  • Laryngoscopy sows the omega sign: The inward curling of the epiglottis to become omega-shaped.
  • Airway films and chest radiographs are done when the work of breathing is moderate to severe.
  • A contrast swallow study or Flexible endoscopic evaluation of swallowing (FEES) is considered when dysphagia is suspected.
  • Complete bronchoscopy is done for those with moderate to severe obstruction.

Treatment
  • Expectant observation for most infants as the spontaneous resolution of symptoms as the child grows is seen.
  • Laryngoesophageal reflux and GERD are treated with proton pump inhibitors or histamine receptor antagonists, considering the possible iron deficiency anaemia.
  • Supraglottoplasty is done in case of severe disease that causes progressive respiratory distress, cyanosis, failure to thrive, or cor pulmonale.
  • Earlier intervention is needed in children with cardiac disease, neurologic disease, pulmonary disorders, or craniofacial anomalies.

Laryngeal papilloma (Option B) is an overgrowth of the epithelium caused by HPV and not by floppy tissues above the vocal cords as seen in the given image.

Chronic epiglottitis (Option C) is diagnosed clinically and laryngoscopy is not usually done. It is an inflammatory condition and may cause stridor but it is not the most common cause and the given image is not of epiglottitis.

Laryngocoele (Option D) is an abnormal dilation of the saccule of the larynx and is not the most common cause of stridor in children.

questions.text: A child was brought to the emergency room, with a fever for 2 days, dyspnea, drooling and inspiratory stridor. Lateral x-ray neck findings were as seen below. Which is the most common organism (in India) that causes this condition in children?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Haemophilus influenza B

  • The given Lateral neck X-ray shows thumb-sign (swollen, rounded epiglottis that resembles a thumb). This sign is highly indicative of epiglottitis, along with symptoms like drooling, high fever, and severe sore throat and the most common organism causing it is Hemophilus influenza B

Acute epiglottitis

Acute Epiglottitis

Life-threatening infection that causes profound swelling of the upper airways, which can lead to asphyxia and respiratory arrest.

Causative Agent

  • Past Era (Pre-vaccine): Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib)
  • Post-vaccine Era:
    • Streptococcus pneumoniae (M/c), Streptococcus pyogenes, non-typeable H. influenzae (Option B), and Staphylococcus aureus (Option C)
    • Hib cases have decreased by 99% due to widespread vaccination

Clinical Features
  • High fever
  • Sore throat
  • Dyspnea
  • Respiratory obstruction
  • Respiratory distress
  • The child appears toxic
  • Difficulty swallowing
  • Labored breathing
  • Drooling
  • Neck hyperextension to maintain airway
  • Tripod position (sitting upright, leaning forward)
  • Stridor is a late sign indicating near-complete airway obstruction
  • Cyanosis
  • Coma

Diagnosis

  • Laryngoscopy: Large, cherry-red, swollen epiglottis
  • Lateral neck X-ray: Thumb sign

Treatment

  • Immediate Treatment:
    • Secure the airway with endotracheal or nasotracheal intubation or, less often, with tracheostomy.
    • Intubation is generally for 2-3 days.
    • Intubation decreases mortality from 6% to <1% in epiglottitis cases.
    • Culture Collection: Blood, epiglottic surface and CSF in certain cases after the airway is stabilized.
  • Antibiotics: Ceftriaxone, cefepime or meropenem given parenterally for 10 days.

Recovery

Symptoms improve with a few days of antibiotics, and the patient may be extubated.

RSV (Resoiratory syncytial virus) (Option D) is incorrect as it is not the most common causative agent of epiglottitis.

questions.text: A 3-year-old was diagnosed with croup. Which of the following is the most common causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Influenza virus

 

Explanation:

Croup, also known as laryngotracheobronchitis, is an upper respiratory tract infection that causes barking cough, stridor, and hoarseness due to inflammation of the larynx and trachea. It is most commonly caused by the parainfluenza virus, followed by the influenza virus. Among the given options, the influenza virus is the most appropriate choice.


 

Laryngotracheobronchitis (Croup): Viral infection of the glottic and subglottic regions

 

Causative Agent
  • Parainfluenza viruses (types 1,2 and 3) cause about 75% cases.
  • Other Viruses:
    • Influenza A and B,
    • Adenovirus,
    • Respiratory syncytial virus,
    • Measles.

Age Group
  • Most common in children aged 3 months to 5 years.
  • Peak incidence occurs in the 2nd year of life.

Initial Symptoms

These symptoms last 1-3 days before development of upper airway obstruction signs and symptoms.

  • Upper respiratory tract infection
  • Rhinorrhea
  • Pharyngitis
  • Mild cough
  • Low-grade fever

Progressive Symptoms

  • Barking cough
  • Hoarseness
  • Inspiratory stridor
  • Fever may reach 39- 40°C (102.2-104°F) or be absent
  • The child prefers to sit up in bed or be held upright
  • Symptoms worsen at night, recur over days and resolve within a week

Physical Examination Findings
  • Hoarse voice
  • Coryza
  • Inflamed pharynx
  • Slightly increased respiratory rate
  • Hypoxia and low oxygen saturation seen only in complete airway obstruction

Diagnosis

  • Clinical diagnosis
  • X-ray PA view of neck: Steeple sign, which is characteristic of subglottic narrowing

 

Treatment

  • Mainstay of Treatment: Focus on airway management and hypoxia treatment (O2).
  • Nebulized Racemic Epinephrine
  • Corticosteroids (dexamethasone):
    • Decrease edema in laryngeal mucosa
    • Oral steroids beneficial in mild croup
  • Antibiotics are not indicated.

 

Hemophilus influenza (Option A) is associated with epiglottitis, not croup.

 

Streptococcus pneumonia (Option B) is associated with pneumonia, otitis media, or meningitis, but not croup.

 

Diphtheria (Option D) is associated with diphtheria, which presents with a pseudomembrane in the throat and can lead to airway obstruction, but it is distinct from croup.

questions.text: A child is brought to the hospital with respiratory distress and biphasic stridor. The radiograph is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Acute laryngotracheobronchitis

Explanation:

  • A child with biphasic stridor and respiratory distress are hallmark features of acute laryngotracheobronchitis.

Laryngotracheobronchitis (Croup):

Refers to viral infection of the glottic and subglottic regions.

Causative Agent
  • Parainfluenza viruses (types 1,2 and 3) cause about 75% cases.
  • Other Viruses:
    • Influenza A and B
    • Adenovirus
    • Respiratory syncytial virus
    • Measles

Age Group
  • Most common in children aged 3 months to 5 years.
  • Peak incidence occurs in the 2nd year of life.

Initial Symptoms

These symptoms last 1-3 days before development of upper airway obstruction signs and symptoms.

  • Upper Respiratory tract infection
  • Rhinorrhea
  • Pharyngitis
  • Mild cough
  • Low-grade fever

Progressive Symptoms

  • Barking cough
  • Hoarseness
  • Inspiratory stridor
  • Fever may reach 39-40°C (102.2-104°F) or be absent.
  • Child prefers to sit up in bed or be held upright.
  • Symptoms worsen at night, recur over days and resolve within a week.

Physical Examination Findings
  • Hoarse voice
  • Coryza
  • Normal to moderately inflamed pharynx.
  • Slightly increased respiratory rate.
  • Hypoxia and low oxygen saturation (seen only in complete airway obstruction).

Diagnosis

 
  • Clinical diagnosis
  • X-ray PA view of neck: Steeple sign, which is characteristic of subglottic narrowing

Treatment

  • Mainstay of Treatment: Focus on airway management and hypoxia treatment.
  • Mild croup: Single dose dexamethasone.
  • Moderate to severe croup: Nebulized epinephrine in addition to dexamethasone.
  • Nebulized Racemic Epinephrine: Used for moderate to severe stridor at rest, possible need for intubation, respiratory distress and hypoxia.
  • Corticosteroids:
    • Decrease edema in laryngeal mucosa
    • Oral steroids beneficial in mild croup
    • Dexamethasone 0.6 mg/kg single dose; as low as 0.15 mg/kg may be effective.
  • Antibiotics are not indicated.


Acute epiglottitis (Option A) typically presents with a rapidly worsening fever, difficulty breathing, drooling, and a child in a hyperextended neck position to ease breathing. Stridor is a late sign, often accompanied by a toxic appearance. Radiographs show the thumb sign (enlarged epiglottis).

 

Foreign body aspiration (Option C) often presents with a sudden onset of symptoms, including coughing, choking, and gagging, followed by localized wheezing or differences in breath sounds on auscultation.

 

Laryngomalacia (Option D) is a congenital condition characterized by chronic inspiratory stridor in infants, typically low-pitched and worsening with activity or crying. Laryngoscopy reveals an omega-shaped epiglottis, a key diagnostic feature.

questions.text: A neonate was born to a controlled gestational diabetes mother. At the time of birth, he was fine but 4 days later, he developed dyspnea with Spo2 80% at room air. What is the initial management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Give 100% O2

Explanation:

In this scenario, the child developed the symptoms after 4 days of birth, and the aetiology can be cardiac (cyanotic heart disease) or pulmonary. Hence, the best method is to give 100% oxygen to the neonate to distinguish the cause.

If the saturation improves, the cause is respiratory, and if not, the cause is cardiogenic. This is called the hyperoxia test.

Hyperoxia test for distinguishing CCHD from pulmonary disease

  • This is the initial method to differentiate congenital critical heart disease (CCHD) from pulmonary disease.
  • Procedure:
    • Measure arterial blood gases (ABG) first at room air and then again after administering 100% oxygen for 10 minutes.
  • Expected results in CCHD:
    • Neonates with CCHD usually fail to increase PaO2 above 100 mm Hg with 100% oxygen.
  • Expected Results in Pulmonary Disease:
    • In pulmonary disease, PaO2 typically increases to ≥100 mm Hg when given 100% oxygen, as ventilation-perfusion mismatch is corrected.
  • Interpretation:
    • A positive result (failure to increase PaO2) suggests a cardiac origin, warranting further cardiac evaluation to rule out CCHD.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of cystic fibrosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Biliary atresia

Explanation:

  • Biliary atresia is not a characteristic feature of cystic fibrosis. While cystic fibrosis can cause liver damage and biliary cirrhosis due to obstructed bile ducts, biliary atresia is a separate congenital condition where there is a complete absence or abnormality of the bile ducts, leading to severe liver damage and jaundice.
  • Cystic fibrosis (CF) is an autosomal recessive genetic disorder caused by mutations in the CFTR gene on chromosome 7q31.2 (m/c mutation is ΔF508), leading to a defective CFTR protein.

 

Pathophysiology of Cystic Fibrosis:

 

CFTR Protein Dysfunction
  • Defective chloride transport across epithelial cells
  • Increased sodium absorption
  • Decreased water movement leading to dehydrated mucous surfaces

Respiratory System
  • Thick, viscous mucus leads to airway obstruction and bacterial colonization
  • Chronic infection and inflammation
  • Bronchiectasis, atelectasis, and respiratory failure

Gastrointestinal System
  • Thick secretions block pancreatic ducts leading to enzyme insufficiency
  • Malabsorption of fats and proteins
  • Meconium ileus in neonates
  • Distal Intestinal Obstruction Syndrome (DIOS)

Hepatobiliary System
  • Bile duct obstruction leading to biliary cirrhosis

Sweat Glands
  • Impaired chloride reabsorption leading to salty sweat

Reproductive System
  • Congenital absence of the vas deferens in males leading to azoospermia and infertility.
  • Defective CFTR in the cervix leads to the production of thick, dehydrated cervical mucus that blocks the cervical os, impairing sperm entry and reducing fertility.

Clinical Features of Cystic Fibrosis

 

System

Clinical Features

Respiratory
  • Chronic productive cough
  • Recurrent respiratory infections
  • Nasal polyps (Option A ruled out)
  • Bronchiectasis

Gastrointestinal
  • Greasy stools (steatorrhea)
  • Failure to thrive
  • Rectal prolapse
  • Malabsorption
  • Meconium ileus in newborns (Option C ruled out)

Genitourinary

Infertility in males (due to congenital absence of vas deferens),

delayed puberty

Others

Digital clubbing, Bleeding diathesis (Option D ruled out), salt loss syndromes (hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis)

questions.text: A newborn child is brought to the emergency department with respiratory difficulty. The doctor evaluated, and the child was found to have a posterolateral defect, as shown in the x-ray given. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Bochdalek hernia

Explanation:

The clinical features and X-ray show a congenital diaphragmatic hernia, and the most common type that appears in the posterolateral part on the left side is the Bochdalek hernia.

Diaphragmatic Hernia:

  • It is a communication between the abdominal and thoracic cavities, which may or may not involve abdominal contents in the thorax.
  • Aetiology: Rarely traumatic, usually congenital.
  • Symptoms and Prognosis: Dependent on the location of the defect and associated anomalies.

Types of diaphragmatic hernia:

  • Hiatal hernia (Option C): Occurs at the esophageal hiatus.
  • Paraesophageal Hernia: Near the esophageal hiatus.
  • Morgagni Hernia (Option B): Retro-sternal, occurring in the foramen of Morgagni (2–6% of CDH cases).
  • Bochdalek Hernia: Occurs in the posterolateral portion of the diaphragm; most common, accounting for 90% of congenital diaphragmatic hernias (CDH). It occurs predominantly on the left side (80-90%).

Pathology and etiology:

  • CDH involves a diaphragmatic defect and often leads to pulmonary hypoplasia.
  • Pulmonary hypoplasia is due to both compression of the lungs and, in some cases, may precede the diaphragmatic defect.
  • Pathological features include reduced pulmonary mass, abnormal alveolar septa, thickened alveoli, and biochemical imbalances such as surfactant deficiency.

Clinical Features:

  • Symptoms include respiratory distress, tachypnea, cyanosis, and scaphoid abdomen.
  • Infants may show delayed symptoms and present with vomiting or mild respiratory distress.

Diagnosis:

  • CDH is often diagnosed prenatally via ultrasound (16-24 weeks) and fetal MRI.
  • Key findings: polyhydramnios, chest mass, mediastinal shift, abdominal organs in the chest, and fetal hydrops.
  • After birth, a chest X-ray confirms the diagnosis.

Treatment:

  • Initial Management:
    • Birth in a tertiary care centre with expertise in CDH management is essential.
    • Immediate stabilization includes intubation, gastric decompression, and central venous and arterial access.
    • Goal oxygenation: preductal SpO2 ≥85%.
    • Gentle ventilation and permissive hypercapnia are recommended.
  • Ventilation Strategies:
    • Conventional mechanical ventilation, HFOV, and ECMO are primary methods.
    • Permissive hypercapnia and low-pressure ventilation reduce lung injury.
    • Inhaled nitric oxide (iNO) may be used to manage pulmonary hypertension.
  • Extracorporeal Membrane Oxygenation (ECMO):
    • ECMO is used when conventional ventilation fails.
    • The duration of ECMO may be longer in CDH infants than in other conditions.
  • Surgical Repair:
    • Repair is typically done after stabilization (48 hours post-birth).
    • A subcostal approach is preferred, with a focus on primary repair if possible.
    • If primary repair is not feasible, synthetic patches (e.g., Gore-Tex) may be used.
    • Postoperative monitoring for complications like pulmonary hypertension, bleeding, and bowel obstruction is crucial.

Novel Strategies:

  • Fetal lung-to-head ratio (LHR) on ultrasound is a reliable predictor of outcomes.
  • Fetoscopic tracheal occlusion shows promise for severe cases, but more research is needed.

Traumatic diaphragmatic hernia (Option D) is not the likely diagnosis in the given scenario since there is no significant history of trauma that may indicate this diagnosis.

questions.text: A 3-month-old child has a respiratory rate of 56/min with no chest indrawing and no danger signs. As per IMNCI what is the most appropriate diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Pneumonia

Explanation:

The fast breathing and no other danger signs represent pneumonia as per the IMNCI classification.

Assessment and Classification of the Sick Child (Age 2 Months Up to 5 Years)

  • Initial Assessment: A thorough history from the mother is essential
  • Check for General Danger Signs:

Ask

Look

Action
  • Able to drink or breastfeed?
  • Does the child vomit everything?
  • H/O convulsions during this illness?
  • Lethargic or unconscious?
  • Currently convulsing?
  • If any danger signs are present, the child needs URGENT attention.
  • Assess Cough or Difficulty Breathing:
    • Ask: How long has the child had a cough or difficulty breathing?
    • Look, Listen, Feel: Count the breaths in one minute (use respiratory rate timers if available).
    • Fast Breathing Criteria:
      • Age 2 months up to 12 months: Fast breathing is 50 breaths per minute or more.
      • Age 12 months up to 5 years: Fast breathing is 40 breaths per minute or more.
  • Look for chest indrawing
  • Look and listen for stridor, wheeze
  • Check for central cyanosis
  • Check oxygen saturation
  • Check the AVPU scale (Alert, Voice, Pain, Unresponsive)
  • Assess for possible asthma/TB if wheezing with chest in-drawing or fast breathing is present.

Classify the condition:

Classification

Signs

Treatment

Severe Pneumonia or Very Severe Disease (Option C)
  • Any general danger sign

OR

  • Oxygen saturation <90%
  • Stridor in calm child
  • Central cyanosis
  • Convulsions
  • AVPU = V, P, or U
  • Start oxygen therapy if saturation < 90%.
  • Administer Benzyl Penicillin & Gentamicin.
  • Give diazepam if convulsing.
  • Prevent low blood sugar.
  • Treat wheeze if present.
  • Urgent referral or admission.

Pneumonia (Option A)
  • Chest indrawing in calm child

OR

  • Fast breathing

AND

  • No signs of severe pneumonia
  • Administer Amoxicillin Dispersible Tablet.
  • Give Vitamin A.
  • Treat wheeze if present.
  • Follow up in 5 days
  • Advise on immediate return signs.

No Pneumonia: Cough or Cold

No signs of pneumonia or very severe disease
  • Treat wheeze if present - salbutamol for 5 days
  • Advise on immediate return signs.

Options B and D are incorrect.

questions.text: Chloride level in sweat is used in the diagnosis of which disease:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Cystic fibrosis

Explanation: Chloride level in sweat is used to diagnose cystic fibrosis.

Cystic fibrosis is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by a mutation in the CFTR gene located on chromosome 7q32.

Diagnostic Criteria for Cystic Fibrosis (CF):

  • Presence of one or more phenotypic features (or)
  • A history of Cystic Fibrosis in a sibling (or)
  • A positive neonatal screening test - Dried blood is checked for immunoreactive trypsinogen.

Plus

Laboratory evidence for CFTR (Cystic Fibrosis transmembrane regulator) dysfunction:

  • Two elevated sweat chloride concentrations (highly specific test) obtained at separate labs > 60 mEq/L (or)
  • Identification of two Cystic Fibrosis mutations by DNA sequencing (or)
  • An abnormal transepithelial nasal potential difference measurement

Investigations:

  1. Sweat Chloride Test:
    • The gold standard for CF diagnosis, especially in symptomatic patients.
    • Pilocarpine iontophoresis is used to stimulate sweat production, and chloride concentration is measured.
    • A chloride concentration of:
      • ≥60 mmol/L confirms CF in children and adults.
      • 30-59 mmol/L indicates intermediate results, requiring further evaluation.
    • In CF- sweat chloride levels are increased, while chloride levels are decreased in pancreatic secretions.
  2. Genetic Testing:
    • Genetic testing, particularly for the common F508del mutation, is conducted if CF is suspected.
    • Expanded genetic panels may include hundreds of mutations but are often limited in efficacy for rare variants.
  3. Nasal Potential Difference (NPD):
    • This test measures the bioelectric properties of the respiratory epithelium, reflecting CFTR function.
    • In CF, defective chloride and sodium transport leads to abnormal potential differences.
    • NPD testing is helpful when sweat chloride tests are inconclusive and can provide a more direct assessment of CFTR functionality.
  4. Other Tests:
    • Fecal Elastase: Used to evaluate pancreatic exocrine function, which is impaired in CF.
    • Chest Imaging: Although not diagnostic, imaging can assess lung disease severity, showing bronchiectasis and hyperinflation common in CF patients.
    • Transepithelial Intestinal and Rectal Biopsies: These can be used to directly evaluate CFTR function, though they are generally reserved for research or challenging cases.
    • Serum electrolytes - hyponatremic, hypokalemic, hypochloremic alkalosis are seen in CF (contraction alkalosis)

 

Phenylketonuria (Option A) is caused by a deficiency in phenylalanine hydroxylase, leading to high levels of phenylalanine. It is diagnosed by measuring plasma phenylalanine concentration, not by sweat chloride testing.

Gaucher’s disease (Option C) results from a deficiency of ß-glucosidase, and diagnosis is made by testing ß-glucosidase activity in fibroblasts or leukocytes, along with genetic testing, not by sweat chloride levels.

Osteogenesis imperfecta (Option D) is caused by mutations in type-1 collagen genes, and it is diagnosed through genetic testing or DNA sequencing, not through sweat chloride measurement.

questions.text: An infant presents with recurrent chest infections and tachypnea. Identify the likely clinical condition.
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Congenital Cystic Adenomatoid Malformation (CCAM):

  • CCAM is a developmental abnormality of the lung characterized by cystic lesions that can cause lung dysfunction and respiratory issues. It often presents with recurrent respiratory infections and tachypnea due to the compromised lung tissue.
  • The recurrent chest infections and tachypnea are consistent with CCAM, as the cystic lesions in the lung can lead to chronic respiratory problems and increased susceptibility to infections.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Right-sided Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia (CDH):

  • CDH occurs when there is a defect in the diaphragm that allows abdominal organs to move into the chest cavity, impairing lung development and function. It often presents with respiratory distress shortly after birth.
  • Although CDH can cause tachypnea and respiratory distress, it typically presents more acutely and may be associated with other signs such as mediastinal shift or absence of breath sounds on the affected side. Recurrent chest infections are less characteristic.

Option C - Congenital Lobar Emphysema:

  • This condition involves overinflation of a lobe of the lung, which can compress adjacent lung tissue and cause respiratory distress. It usually presents with respiratory symptoms in the newborn period but is less commonly associated with recurrent infections.
  • While congenital lobar emphysema can cause tachypnea and respiratory issues, recurrent chest infections are not a typical feature. The clinical presentation is less consistent with this diagnosis compared to CCAM.

Option D - Cystic Fibrosis:

  • Cystic fibrosis is a genetic disorder affecting the respiratory, digestive, and reproductive systems. It leads to thick, sticky mucus production that can cause chronic respiratory infections and other complications.
  • Although cystic fibrosis can cause recurrent respiratory infections and tachypnea, it usually presents with additional symptoms such as failure to thrive, gastrointestinal issues, and a positive sweat test. The acute presentation in a newborn with recurrent infections is less characteristic.

questions.text: INSURE technique is used in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Option A - Respiratory Distress Syndrome:

  • The INSURE technique (INtubation, SURfactant administration, and Extubation) is specifically designed to treat respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) in preterm infants. This technique aims to administer surfactant therapy effectively while minimizing the duration of mechanical ventilation and associated complications.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D do not require the INSURE technique.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a suitable method for free-flow oxygen delivery to a newborn baby?

choices.text: Oxygen tube kept close to the baby's nose and mouth
Oxygen mask placed over the baby's mouth and nose
Self-inflating bag attached to an oxygen mask placed over baby's mouth and nose
A reservoir bag attached to an oxygen mask kept over the baby's nose and mouth

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Self-inflating bag attached to an oxygen mask placed over the baby's mouth and nose:

  • A self-inflating bag is designed to deliver positive pressure ventilation (PPV) and is not intended for free-flow oxygen delivery. It provides a higher flow rate and pressure suitable for resuscitation rather than the gentle, continuous flow needed for free-flow oxygen.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Oxygen tube kept close to the baby's nose and mouth:

  • This method provides free-flow oxygen by directing the flow from a tube close to the baby's face, ensuring a continuous supply without the need for direct contact with the nose or mouth.

Option B - Oxygen mask placed over the baby's mouth and nose:

  • An oxygen mask can be used to deliver free-flow oxygen efficiently, ensuring that the baby inhales the oxygen without requiring active breathing support from the mask itself.

Option D - A reservoir bag attached to an oxygen mask kept over the baby's nose and mouth:

  • Like option B, a reservoir bag attached to an oxygen mask can deliver high concentrations of oxygen when placed over the baby’s nose and mouth, suitable for providing free-flow oxygen

questions.text:
Choose the correct statements for cystic fibrosis:

i. Increased Cl- in sweat.
ii. Decreased Cl- in sweat.
iii. Increased Cl- in pancreatic juice.
iv. Decreased Cl- in pancreatic juice.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) i and iv

Explanation:

Cystic fibrosis (CF) is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) gene. The CFTR protein regulates chloride channels in various organs, including the sweat glands and the pancreas, which leads to the clinical features observed in CF.

  • Increased chloride in sweat (i): In CF, the CFTR defect leads to impaired chloride reabsorption in sweat glands. This results in abnormally high chloride levels in sweat, which is used as a diagnostic test for CF (sweat chloride test). A sweat chloride level >80 mmol/L is diagnostic of CF.
  • Decreased chloride in pancreatic juice (iv): In CF, the CFTR defect also impairs chloride secretion in the pancreas. This results in thick and adherent exocrine secretions that obstruct pancreatic ducts, impair enzyme production, and lead to malabsorption and steatorrhea.

Cystic fibrosis

Genetic Basis
  • Gene: CFTR (Cystic Fibrosis Transmembrane Conductance Regulator)
  • Location: Chromosome 7q31.2
  • Common Mutation: ΔF508
  • Inheritance: Autosomal recessive

Pathophysiology

 

  • CFTR Dysfunction: Defective chloride transport, increased sodium absorption, dehydrated mucus
  • Metabolic: (Hypokalemia) Due to excessive loss of potassium through sweat and impaired renal potassium handling
  • Respiratory: Airway obstruction, bacterial colonization, bronchiectasis, respiratory failure
  • Gastrointestinal: Pancreatic duct obstruction, malabsorption, Distal Intestinal Obstruction Syndrome
  • Sweat Glands: Salty sweat
  • Reproductive:
    Infertility in males: Congenital absence of the vas deferens in males leading to azoospermia and infertility.
    Infertility in females: Defective CFTR in the cervix leads to the production of thick, dehydrated cervical mucus that blocks the cervical os, impairing sperm entry and reducing fertility.

Clinical Features
  • Respiratory: Chronic productive cough, recurrent infections, bronchiectasis
  • Gastrointestinal: Steatorrhea, malabsorption, meconium ileus, failure to thrive
  • Genitourinary: Infertility (males), delayed puberty
  • Other: Digital clubbing, salt-loss syndromes (Contraction alkalosis)

Diagnosis

Diagnostic Criteria

Requirement 1: Any ONE of the following

 

  • Clinical Features: Presence of typical features
  • Family History: A sibling with diagnosed cystic fibrosis
  • Newborn Screening: Positive result indicating risk for CF
  • IRT Screening: Elevated Immunoreactive Trypsinogen (IRT) for pancreatic insufficiency

Requirement 2: At least ONE of the following

Laboratory Evidence:

 

  • Sweat Chloride Test: Two elevated sweat chloride concentrations on separate days ≥60 mMol/L (Pilocarpine iontophoresis method)
  • CFTR Mutations: Identification of two CFTR mutations
  • Nasal Potential Difference: Abnormal measurement

Microbes
  • <18 years: Staphylococcus aureus
  • >18 years: Pseudomonas aeruginosa

 

  • Burkholderia cepacia: High mortality, low incidence

Management Strategies
  • Airway Clearance: Chest physiotherapy, percussion, postural drainage
  • Infection Control: Antibiotics, CFTR modulators
  • Nutritional Support: High-calorie diet, PERT, vitamin supplementation (A, D, E, K)
  • Other: Insulin for CFRD, bone health management

Advanced Therapies
  • CFTR Modulators: Ivacaftor, lumacaftor, Trikafta
  • Trikafta: Elexacaftor-Tezacaftor-Ivacaftor (≥2 years old), improves lung function, reduces sweat chloride

questions.text: A 9-month-old child is brought to the PHC with a fever and cough. She is feeding well and has normal urine output. On examination, a respiratory rate of 48 breaths/min is found, and no chest indrawing is seen. What is the next step of management?

choices.text: Explain danger signs and send home
No pneumonia—Give amoxyclav + paracetamol and send home
Refer as the child has severe pneumonia

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Explain danger signs and send home

Explanation:

  • The clinical scenario involves a 9-month-old child with fever and cough but without severe symptoms like chest indrawing, which would indicate severe pneumonia. The child's respiratory rate (RR) is 48 breaths per minute, which is normal for this age (RR >60/min would be abnormal for infants).

According to the IMNCI guidelines, pneumonia is suspected if:

  • RR >60 breaths/min for infants <2 months
  • RR >50 breaths/min for infants 2-12 months
  • RR >40 breaths/min for children 12 months to 6 years
  • Lower chest wall indrawing, a sign of moderate pneumonia, is absent here.
  • Severe pneumonia involves danger signs like lethargy, inability to drink, persistent vomiting, and convulsions, which are not present in this case.

Based on this assessment, the child does not have severe pneumonia. The next step is to explain the danger signs to the caregiver and send the child home with appropriate follow-up instructions.

Pneumonia

Etiology

  • Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV): Leading viral cause of pneumonia in infants.
  • Streptococcus pneumoniae: M/c bacterial cause in children, particularly aged 1-3 months.
  • Pneumocystis jirovecii: Common in HIV-infected infants, especially where ART and PCP prophylaxis are limited.
  • Other Bacteria: E. coli, Gram-negative bacilli, Haemophilus influenzae, Group B streptococcus.
  • Other Viruses: Rhinoviruses, parainfluenza, influenza, human metapneumovirus, adenovirus.
  • Other Fungal: Histoplasma, Aspergillus, Blastomyces, Cryptococcus, mucormycosis, Coccidioides.
  • Parasitic: Ascaris, Strongyloides.
  • Mycobacterium: Mycobacterium tuberculosis, Mycobacterium avium complex.

Assessment and Classification of the Sick Child (Age 2 Months Up to 5 Years)

  • Initial Assessment: A thorough history from the mother is essential
  • Check for General Danger Signs:

Ask

Look

Action
  • Able to drink or breastfeed?
  • Does the child vomit everything?
  • H/O convulsions during this illness?
  • Lethargic or unconscious?
  • Currently convulsing?
  • If any danger signs are present, the child needs URGENT attention.

 

Assess Cough or Difficulty Breathing

Ask:

  • How long has the child had a cough or difficulty breathing?

Look, Listen, Feel:

  • Count the breaths per minute (use respiratory rate timers if available).
  • Fast Breathing Criteria:
    • Age 2 months up to 12 months: ≥50 breaths per minute.
    • Age 12 months up to 5 years: ≥40 breaths per minute.

Look for:

  • Chest in-drawing.
  • Stridor, wheeze.
  • Central cyanosis.
  • Oxygen saturation.
  • Use the AVPU scale (Alert, Voice, Pain, Unresponsive).

Assess for possible asthma/TB if the child has wheezing with chest in-drawing or fast breathing.

Classification of Pneumonia and Management

Classification

Signs

Treatment

Severe Pneumonia or Very Severe Disease
  • Any general danger sign
  • Oxygen saturation < 90%
  • Stridor in calm child
  • Central cyanosis
  • Convulsions
  • AVPU = V, P, or U
  • Start oxygen therapy if saturation < 90%.
  • Administer Benzyl Penicillin (or Ampicillin) & Gentamicin.
  • Ceftriaxone should be used as a second-line treatment in children with severe pneumonia having failed on the first-line treatment.
  • Give diazepam if convulsing.
  • Prevent hypoglycemia.
  • Treat wheeze if present.
  • Urgent referral or admission.

Pneumonia
  • Chest indrawing in calm child
  • Fast breathing
  • No signs of severe pneumonia
  • Administer Amoxicillin Dispersible Tablets.
  • Give Vitamin A.
  • Treat wheeze if present.
  • Follow-up in 5 days.
  • Advise on immediate return signs.

No Pneumonia (Cough or Cold)
  • No signs of pneumonia or very severe disease.
  • Treat wheeze if present with salbutamol for 5 days.
  • Advise on immediate return signs.

 

No pneumonia—Give amoxyclav + paracetamol and send home (Option B): While this treatment approach could be appropriate for non-severe cases, the child does not meet the criteria for pneumonia based on clinical signs such as the absence of chest indrawing. Instead, explaining the danger signs and monitoring at home is preferred.

Start IV ceftriaxone (Option C): IV ceftriaxone is typically used in cases of severe pneumonia or when the child is unable to tolerate oral medication. This child does not have severe symptoms, so oral antibiotics (if pneumonia were diagnosed) would be sufficient.

Refer as the child has severe pneumonia (Option D): The child does not have severe pneumonia as defined by the IMNCI criteria, which requires the presence of danger signs such as inability to drink or severe difficulty breathing. There is no indication for referral in this case.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy was brought in with a history of chronic cough and foul-smelling stools. His sibling, who had similar complaints, died a few years back. Sweat chloride test and CFTR gene studies were done. CFTR gene codes for proteins involved in the transport of
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Cl-

Explanation:

  • The clinical scenario described is highly suggestive of cystic fibrosis (CF), a genetic disorder caused by mutations in the CFTR (cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator) gene. This gene encodes a chloride channel that plays a crucial role in the transport of chloride ions (Cl-) across epithelial cell membranes, particularly in the sweat glands, respiratory airways, and pancreatic ducts.

Genetic Basis
  • Gene: CFTR (Cystic Fibrosis Transmembrane Conductance Regulator)
  • Location: Chromosome 7q31.2
  • Common Mutation: ΔF508
  • Inheritance: Autosomal recessive

Pathophysiology

 

  • CFTR Dysfunction: Defective chloride transport, increased sodium absorption, dehydrated mucus
  • Metabolic: (Hypokalemia) Due to excessive loss of potassium through sweat and impaired renal potassium handling
  • Respiratory: Airway obstruction, bacterial colonization, bronchiectasis, respiratory failure
  • Gastrointestinal: Pancreatic duct obstruction, malabsorption, Distal Intestinal Obstruction Syndrome
  • Sweat Glands: Salty sweat
  • Reproductive:

Infertility in males: Congenital absence of the vas deferens in males leading to azoospermia and infertility.

Infertility in females: Defective CFTR in the cervix leads to the production of thick, dehydrated cervical mucus that blocks the cervical os, impairing sperm entry and reducing fertility.

Clinical Features
  • Respiratory: Chronic productive cough, recurrent infections, bronchiectasis
  • Gastrointestinal: Steatorrhea, malabsorption, meconium ileus, failure to thrive
  • Genitourinary: Infertility (males), delayed puberty
  • Other: Digital clubbing, salt-loss syndromes (Contraction alkalosis)

Diagnosis

Diagnostic Criteria

Requirement 1: Any ONE of the following

 

  • Clinical Features: Presence of typical features
  • Family History: A sibling with diagnosed cystic fibrosis
  • Newborn Screening: Positive result indicating risk for CF
  • IRT Screening: Elevated Immunoreactive Trypsinogen (IRT) for pancreatic insufficiency

Requirement 2: At least ONE of the following

Laboratory Evidence:

 

  • Sweat Chloride Test: Two elevated sweat chloride concentrations on separate days ≥60 mMol/L (Pilocarpine iontophoresis method)
  • CFTR Mutations: Identification of two CFTR mutations
  • Nasal Potential Difference: Abnormal measurement

Microbes
  • <18 years: Staphylococcus aureus
  • >18 years: Pseudomonas aeruginosa

 

  • Burkholderia cepacia: High mortality, low incidence

Management Strategies
  • Airway Clearance: Chest physiotherapy, percussion, postural drainage
  • Infection Control: Antibiotics, CFTR modulators
  • Nutritional Support:
  • High-calorie diet,
  • Pancreatic Enzyme Replacement Therapy
  • Vitamin supplementation (A, D, E, K)
  • Other: Insulin for CFRD, bone health management

Advanced Therapies
  • CFTR Modulators: Ivacaftor, lumacaftor, Trikafta
  • Trikafta: Elexacaftor-Tezacaftor-Ivacaftor (≥2 years old), improves lung function, reduces sweat chloride

questions.text: A newborn presented with chest retractions, dyspnea, and lethargy. The pediatrician diagnosed the baby with respiratory distress syndrome. This occurs due to a deficiency of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Lecithin

Explanation: Respiratory distress syndrome in a neonate is likely due to a deficiency of Lecithin.

Respiratory Distress Syndrome/Hyaline Membrane Disease (HMD):

  • It is a common respiratory condition in preterm infants (<34 weeks of gestation) caused by surfactant deficiency.
  • Pathophysiology:
    • Surfactant is primarily produced by type II alveolar cells and reduces surface tension, preventing alveolar collapse at the end of expiration.
    • Surfactant is composed of phospholipids, proteins, and lipids.
    • Phosphatidylcholine, also known as lecithin, is a significant phospholipid in mature surfactants.
    • Its production begins around 20 weeks of gestation and peaks at 35 weeks, so infants born before 35 weeks are at higher risk for RDS due to insufficient surfactant.
    • Without adequate surfactant, alveoli collapse during expiration, impairing gas exchange and causing tissue hypoxia. This results in increased pulmonary pressure, ischemic damage, and the formation of a hyaline membrane from protein transudation.
  • Clinical Features: Respiratory distress within the first 6 hours of life is characterised by tachypnea, retractions, grunting, cyanosis, and decreased air entry.
  • Typical X-ray findings in RDS include:
    • Ground glass haziness of lungs: Represents diffuse alveolar atelectasis, commonly seen in RDS.
    • Presence of air bronchogram: Air-filled bronchi are visible against the hazy, collapsed alveoli, a classic feature of RDS. Air bronchogram can be seen in parenchymal pathology of the lung, such as consolidation, pulmonary alveolar proteinosis.
    • Reticulogranular pattern: Another term for the ground-glass appearance, indicating the fine, granular pattern throughout the lungs characteristic of RDS.
  • Management:
    • Neonates with this condition require admission to the neonatal intensive care unit, IV fluids, and appropriate respiratory support.
    • Further management details are depicted in the table below,

 

Dipalmitoyl inositol (Option A): While it serves as a precursor in secondary messenger systems and plays roles in cell signaling and membrane trafficking, it is not involved in surfactant production or the prevention of respiratory distress syndrome.
 

Sphingomyelin (Option C) is the dominant sphingolipid in the plasma membrane. The lecithin/sphingomyelin (L/S) ratio in amniotic fluid is a marker of fetal lung maturity, but sphingomyelin itself does not directly contribute to alveolar stability.
 

Dipalmitoylphosphatidylethanolamine (Option D): Found in cell membranes, it lacks the essential surface tension-reducing properties of dipalmitoylphosphatidylcholine (lecithin), which is crucial for preventing alveolar collapse and respiratory distress syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following medicines can be used in a child with bronchiolitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Ribavirin: Nebulized ribavarin can be used in immunocompromised patients with bronchiolitis.

Incorrect Options: Options B, C, and D are not given in the treatment of bronchiolitis.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis for an infant who is admitted with respiratory distress, prolonged expiration, rhonchi in the chest, and hyperinflation shown on a CXR?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Bronchiolitis

  • The patient’s presentation with respiratory distress, prolonged expiration, rhonchi in the chest, and hyperinflation shown on a chest x-ray is suggestive of bronchiolitis.
  • Bronchiolitis is caused by a viral infection, most commonly respiratory syncytial virus (RSV).

Incorrect Options - A, B, and C do not show hyperinflation on chest x-ray.

questions.text: Which of the following is absent in a child with cystic fibrosis?

choices.text: Sweat chloride test chloride conc of 70mEq/L

questions.solution:
Correct option C - Hyperkalemia:

  • Hyperkalemia is not seen in a child with cystic fibrosis.
  • Cystic fibrosis primarily affects the exocrine glands, leading to abnormal production and secretion of thick, sticky mucus in various organs.
  • It is commonly associated with electrolyte imbalances such as hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis due to excessive chloride loss in sweat.

Incorrect Options - A, B, and D are present in a child with cystic fibrosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indicator of fetal lung maturity?

choices.text: Nile blue test showing >50% of blue cells

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Nile blue test showing >50% of blue cells: 

  • The Nile blue test is used to assess the presence of mature surfactant in the lungs.
  • The presence of more than 50% blue cells suggests the presence of immature surfactant and indicates the need for further lung development.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A: Lecithin-sphingomyelin (L/S) ratio > 2.5:

  • The L/S ratio measures the ratio of two phospholipids, lecithin, and sphingomyelin, in the amniotic fluid.
  • A ratio greater than 2.5 indicates that the fetus has mature lungs and is capable of producing sufficient surfactant.

Option B: Positive shake test:

  • The shake test, also known as the foam stability test or bubble stability test, is another method used to assess fetal lung maturity.
  • In this test, amniotic fluid is shaken vigorously, and the presence of stable foam indicates the presence of surfactant, suggesting lung maturity.

Option C: Increased phosphatidyl glycerol:

  • Phosphatidyl glycerol (PG) is a phospholipid component of surfactant.
  • Increased levels of PG in the amniotic fluid are associated with fetal lung maturity.
  • The presence of PG is considered a positive indicator of lung maturity.

Incorrect options:

Option A: Administer IV antibiotics and observe: Intravenous (IV) antibiotics are usually reserved for severe infections or cases where oral antibiotics cannot be administered. In this case, the child's symptoms are not indicative of severe illness, and IV antibiotics would not be necessary at this stage.

Option B: Administer IV antibiotics and refer to a higher center: Referral to a higher center is typically reserved for cases that require specialized care or management beyond the capacity of the current healthcare facility. In this case, the child's symptoms do not suggest the need for immediate referral to a higher center.

Option D: Administer only home remedies: Home remedies alone are not sufficient for managing respiratory tract infections, especially if there is a suspicion of a bacterial infection. While supportive care measures like maintaining hydration and providing symptomatic relief can be recommended, appropriate antibiotic therapy is often required to treat bacterial infections.
